title: Manas National Park
short_description: A UNESCO World Heritage Site known for its Project Tiger, rare golden langur, and red panda.
long_description: Manas National Park is a UNESCO Natural World Heritage site, a Project Tiger reserve, an elephant reserve and a biosphere reserve in Assam, India. Located in the Himalayan foothills, it is contiguous with the Royal Manas National Park in Bhutan. The park is known for its rare and endangered endemic wildlife such as the Assam roofed turtle, hispid hare, golden langur and pygmy hog. Manas is famous for its population of the Wild water buffalo. With the Manas River flowing through it, the park offers stunning landscape views ranging from forested hills to alluvial grasslands and tropical evergreen forests.
wildlife_significance: Biosphere Reserve. Critical habitat for Pygmy Hog, Golden Langur, and Hispid Hare (endemic species).
guides_and_tips: It's less crowded than Kaziranga, offering a more serene experience. Bansbari is the central zone.
how_to_reach: By Air: Guwahati (145 km). By Rail: Barpeta Road (32 km) is the nearest station.
permits_and_fees: Permits available at the Field Director's office on Barpeta Road or at entry gates.
conservation_notes: Recovering well from past socio-political unrest. Rhino reintroduction has been successful here.
sample_itinerary: Day 1: Drive from Guwahati to Manas. Check-in. Evening tea by the river. Day 2: Early morning Elephant Safari. Breakfast. River Rafting. Afternoon Jeep Safari. Day 3: Morning drive to Bhutan border (Mathanguri). Departure.
safety_tips: Follow armed guard instructions strictly. Do not venture close to the river banks on foot.

opening_hours.time_notes: Safari timings typical of Assam parks.

pricing_metadata.disclaimer: Prices are indicative and subject to change by park authorities.
